history.content:
The mechanical engineering department offers a controls course ME 132 that has a prereq of Math 53,54, Physics 7AB.  http://guide.berkeley.edu/courses/mec_eng/

ME 132 is similar to EE 120 but focuses more on mechanical systems.  Additionally, ME 132 + EE 16A can satisfy prereqs for more advanced control theory courses like ME C134 (same as EE C128).

---

I'd recommend taking EE120 (though 132 suggested above is also a good/valid choice).  It will introduce the background knowledge (LTI systems etc) necessary and delve a bit into basic control (PID control for instance) near the end.  The reason I'd suggest 120 over 132 is because 120 will also explore some digital signal processing as well, which you may find interesting or useful in the future (for example, in sensing for self driving cars).  In general though, no, there is no class on control theory without pre-reqs because control itself is a specific field of systems theory, and you therefore must have some prior knowledge (it's like trying to learn about database systems without knowing what a data structure is).

---

+1 for ME132 or EE120.  With ME132 or EE120 plus your previous EE16A, you should be fine with taking EE C128/ME C134 the following semester.

The mechanical engineering department offers a controls course ME 132 that has a prereq of Math 53,54, Physics 7AB.  http://guide.berkeley.edu/courses/mec_eng/

ME 132 is similar to EE 120 but focuses more on mechanical systems.  Additionally, ME 132 + EE 16A can satisfy prereqs for more advanced control theory courses like ME C134 (same as EE C128).

ME 132 is similar to EE 120 but focuses more on mechanical systems.  Additionally, ME 132 + EE 16A can satisfy prereqs for more advanced control theory courses like ME C134 (same as EE C128).

I'd recommend taking EE120 (though 132 suggested above is also a good/valid choice).  It will introduce the background knowledge (LTI systems etc) necessary and delve a bit into basic control (PID control for instance) near the end.  The reason I'd suggest 120 over 132 is because 120 will also explore some digital signal processing as well, which you may find interesting or useful in the future (for example, in sensing for self driving cars).  In general though, no, there is no class on control theory that has no pre-reqs because control itself is a specific field of systems theory, and you therefore must have some prior knowledge.

The mechanical engineering department offers a controls course ME 132 that has a prereq of Math 53,54, Physics 7AB.  http://guide.berkeley.edu/courses/mec_eng/

ME 132 is similar to EE 120 but focuses more on mechanical systems.  Additionally, ME 132 + EE 16A can satisfy prereqs for more advanced control theory courses like ME C134 (same as EE C128).
There's a reason that 16B is more than half control and ML, with another third at least nominally related to signal processing that is also core to things like understanding control and vision.

See title.

The reason I ask is because I am doing research in ML and using it to make robots learn better. I see things from control theory pop up from time to time and would like to have a more formal exposure to it. I found that the EE department offers some courses (128 and 221A came to mind), but my EE knowledge is pretty basic (I only took EE 16A). Do I need to take EE 16B + 120 before I would be prepared to take those courses? Or is there a course that does not assume an EE background?
history.subject: Are there any control theory courses that don't assume that you have prior knowledge in EE?
